body: I have encountered this error during batch ingestion task. And I am pretty sure I have not specified -XX:MaxDirectMemorySize on my middle manager. Does it mean my physical machine is too small to process this task? 16G of ram running manager and 3 peons.
@fjy Signed the ICLA.

Hi @nishantmonu51 and @gianm,
I just wonder if this is a legitimate change or.. it's just intendedly missed. Could you please take a look?
@HyukjinKwon: thanks for the PR, It was just missed in the refactoring.
üëç
:+1: (a UT would be nice)

From the discussion it seems like it's worth a shot to separate the encoding and compression, which I'll call _encoding format_ and _compression strategy_. My interpretation is that _compression strategy_ should be unaware of the data type and size, so it must decompress an entire compressed block to access the content. _encoding format_ is anything that does not fit this description, and it would interpret the uncompressed content from the _compression strategy_.

This means if the _compression strategy_ is anything other than _none_ (which indicate no compression strategy should be used), then it require block layout. If no strategy is used, then there is no reason to use block layout as it creates overhead by copying uncompressed blocks. So there would be the choice of which _encoding format_ and _compression strategy_ to use, while whether or not to use block layout is determined by the _compression strategy_ chosen.

@drcrallen When the hit rates are depressed, is the majority of the cluster running 0.9.1 or 0.9.0? #2690 changed cache keys for all of the filters, so I would expect a single 0.9.1 node amongst a sea of 0.9.0s to experience depressed hit rates.

If that's what's going on, you should see a difference if you split the hit rate by "has filters" vs "does not have filters".

Also if you're using approximate histograms, #2891 adjusted cache keys for those.
@gianm some historicals are on 0.9.1 but not all of them. I'll update this when I have everything on 0.9.1

General FYI, this is a communicative measure rather than a bug report, since it is not obvious if this is actually a bug or an artifact of configuration, or a release not that simply needs to be written.
@himanshug An ugly test is added, test into detail is a little hard.
üëç
@rajk-tetration Thanks for this contribution. We'll try to get to reviewing it soon.
Early results are positive that this is an upgrade side-effect that needs a callout in the release notes and not a regression or drop in caching.
Will have more information after peak.
@gianm: sure, I ll check out the changes.
I was trying the hadoop job in druid .9.1 rc4 and hit the same exact bug on every try. Pulling in @hamlet-lee's PR fixed it and the job ran perfectly. +1
üëç
@gianm is it possible to make the cache keys backwards compatible? Is that something we should strive for between releases?

@xvrl In #2891 no, although in #2690 probably yes? Although in general I don't strive for it (& I think others generally don't either) on the grounds that it would potentially clutter the code, the impact is nil if you use local cache, and probably not too awful if you use remote cache.
Values have returned to nominal levels. Will update release notes.

Added

```
* Some cache keys have changed their calculation methodology. Deployments with centralized caching (like memcached or redis) can expect a drop in cache hit rate until all nodes are upgraded
```

@himanshug @fjy pushed these changes, please take another look when you have a chance:
- rename strategies to "v1" and "v2"
- finish implementing query timeouts
- change default initial buckets value to 1024
- make initial buckets configurable through both runtime properties & query context
- modify the growing to use more of the buffer and also able to reuse some space (start halfway through, then grow upwards, then for the final growth start from 0 so we can re-use all but the last table's space)
- add some more tests
- misc other changes from CR
Failed due to https://github.com/ben-manes/caffeine/pull/93
üëç after  https://github.com/druid-io/druid/pull/3018#discussion_r67976750 gets addressed.

@du00cs adding theta sketch module as a dependency here is not so good, can't we have a test to read some avro data , use GenericRecordAsMap to read a string attribute from it and ensure that the type returned is string instead of avro.UTF8? For example, see AvroStreamInputRowParserTest.buildSomeAvroDatum() ... you can probably use that to create a GenericRecord and use that in your test.
@himanshug Sorry, I will change it soon
@himanshug The case comes  from package parquet-avro, test from parquet-extension is enough. More reasonable test is added, please review again.
üëç
üëç
Committers: Please do not merge until @jon-wei has had a chance to validate things
that behavior would mean if a single metric is bad, but the rest of the row is ok, we would include all but the bad metric, rather than throwing away the entire row.
using that construction would also mean that the adjustment of the try/catch in HadoopDruidIndexerMapper isn't necessary (as ParseExceptions will not be thrown if reportParseExceptions is false)
Agree with @fjy
@gianm @drcrallen - changed it to be consistent with RT. please check again.
üëç
üëç
miss-click sorry about that
@fjy added docs
üëç
The weird thing is the task instantly launched once the shutdown process started, this makes me wonder if there was some reason it was being blocked from the forking task runner's queue being full.

When the middle manager restarted, one task was reporting weird, and the number of tasks was greater than the configured capacity of the node:

```

The only way to get the middle manager responsive again was to delete the task directory for `index_realtime_REDACTED_2016-06-22T18:00:00.000Z_48_0` and restart the middle manager.

Then the middle manager reported

```

And continued as expected.
It is unknown at this time if this is a regression or not.
@acslk there are merge conflicts
@hamlet-lee can we finish this PR up?
I filed https://github.com/druid-io/druid/pull/3172 to better be able to tell what things are holding the worker threads.

I forgot to mention in the original comment that during the shutdown the truant task launched as per the middle manager logs:

Just tried the latest version of this patch, I'm still running into issues.

For testing, I'm running druid 0.9.0 with a batch ingestion job on a remote hadoop cluster (sequenceiq hadoop 2.7.1 in a docker container), and using S3 for both the input file and the deep storage.

In the ingestion spec I have:

```
  "hadoopDependencyCoordinates" : [ "org.apache.hadoop:hadoop-client:2.7.1", "org.apache.hadoop:hadoop-aws:2.7.1" ]
```

Without the patch, I'll get the following hadoop-aws related error:

```

Some more info

If I just take druid 0.9.0 and change the classloader map in Initialization to be keyed by File instead of "extension name", e.g.:
https://github.com/jon-wei/druid/commit/bfde13e890496e473fcb4c688bd11b2a4572c2be

then my batch ingestion job described in the previous comment succeeds.

---

If I take this current patch, and restore the old implementation of   `public static URLClassLoader getClassLoaderForExtension(File extension) throws MalformedURLException` (with the individual file URLs), I no longer see hadoop-aws/hadoop-client related errors, but I get the following instead:

https://github.com/jon-wei/druid/commit/7ddbf55d71c4ec47a751431363c23ce58aa5a9af

```
2016-06-22T22:34:38,476 INFO [task-runner-0-priority-0] org.apache.hadoop.mapreduce.Job - Task Id : attempt_1466634772064_0001_m_000000_2, Status : FAILED

I'm fine either way. No matter what though there should be an additional comment mentioning that the default hadoop coordinates probably need to be changed too (else folks will get confused when druid still tries to pull 2.3.0 at runtime).

This metric corresponds to `/druid/coordinator/v1/loadstatus?simple`

I'm thinking its worth it to add a metric for `/druid/coordinator/v1/loadstatus?full` as well

by any chance is the router talking to broker running on old version ?
@nishantmonu51 no but some historicals are still rolling to 0.9.1
If there was an incompatible change to SegmentMetadataQuery that needs called out in the release notes, and we really shouldn't break queries during upgrades like that.
@nishantmonu51 do you know of a SegmentMetadataQuery change that would cause this?

@drcrallen the rolling update order must be respected; historicals need to be updated before broker/router. Compatibility is not guaranteed otherwise.

This particular change was in #2208.
Normally upgrades aren't so strict, I'll chalk it up to impatience on my part if I can get confirmation after our upgrades finish rolling.

It is worth noting that the node that went over capacity violated the normal logging flow somehow. 

`Coordinator asking Worker[REDACTED_HOST] to add task[index_realtime_REDACTED_DATASOURCE_2016-06-22T18:00:00.000Z_56_0]`
happened BEFORE the log of `55_0` showing the new location, by a few ms. 

I'm not sure if this is expected or not, but it looks like assignment to the worker is supposed to be blocked. Digging more
Also note the rtr pending task launcher was in different threads.
@gianm note that tranquility does NOT like the fact that a task is "RUNNING" but has null host and -1 port

worker select strategy is responsible for ensuring that it selects a worker which has available slot to run the task. WorkerSelectStrategy works on an immutable view of cluster passed to it by RTR. So it is possible that with multiple assignment threads, the select strategy will choose an incorrect worker. 

One possible way to fix this can be to add a check in RTR announceTask() protected by statusLock for capacity and retrying.

I think I found it:

RTR has a guard against multiple things trying to launch on the same worker via `workersWithUnacknowledgedTask.putIfAbsent(immutableZkWorker.get().getWorker().getHost(), task.getId()`. But this is enforced AFTER the check for space on the workers through `strategy.findWorkerForTask`

As such, it is possible for N tasks (where N is the number of launching threads) to all think that worker W has capacity, and for them ALL to pass the check if the exact wrong kind of race occurs. Which means that a worker can be over-subscribed up to N-1 tasks.
